newsitem.title: GERMANY: Paint led to Hindenburg airship tragedy - German TV.
newsitem.headline: Paint led to Hindenburg airship tragedy - German TV.

text.p: A new study indicates that special paint used to protect the airship Hindenburg from sunlight led to its spectacular destruction in 1937, German ARD television said on Wednesday.

The Panorama magazine programme said it would air new evidence on Thursday to counter the long-held assumption that ignition of inflammable hydrogen in the airship caused the fireball that was captured in one of the world's most famous newsreel films.
U.S. researchers used archive film, models and computer simulation to study the explosion of the Hindenburg on May 6, 1937, over its transatlantic terminus at Lakehurst, New Jersey.
NASA space agency scientist Addison Bain said the paint, designed to protect the Hindenburg from sunlight on its trips from Europe, had never been tested or used on other Zeppelins.
Bain said the yellow-red colour of the flames showed that the painted external surface of the airship had caught fire first. "That is no hydrogen fire," he said.
Thirty-five passengers and one of the ground crew died in the explosion, ending the golden age of the airborne cruise liners that had become a defining image of the 1920s and 1930s.

The highly public disaster was a propaganda blow for Nazi Germany, which had hoped to impress the world with the 245-metre ship, and ARD said investigations into the cause were systematically suppressed at the time.
